awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Synchronizing the WAIS Divide and Greenland Ice Cores from 30-65 ka BP Using High-resolution 10Be Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
Welten/1644128 

This award supports a project to use existing samples from the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide ice core to align its timescale with that of the Greenland ice cores using common chronological markers. The upper 2850 m of the WAIS Divide core, which was drilled to a depth of 3405 m, has been dated with high precision. The timescale of the remaining (bottom) 550 m of the core has larger uncertainties, limiting our understanding of the timing of abrupt climate events in Antarctica relative to those in Greenland during the last ice age. The intellectual merit of this project is to further constrain the relative timing of these abrupt climate events in Greenland and Antarctica to obtain crucial insight into the underlying mechanism. The main objective of this project is to improve the current timescale of the WAIS Divide core from 31,000 to 65,000 years ago by synchronizing this core with the Greenland ice cores using common signals in Beryllium-10, a radioactive isotope of Be that is produced in the atmosphere by cosmic rays and is deposited onto the snow within 1-2 years of its production. The 10Be flux is largely independent of climate signals since its production varies with solar activity and the geomagnetic field. This project will further strengthen collaborations between the PI's in Berkeley and Purdue with ice core researchers in the US and Europe, involve undergraduate students in many aspects of its research, and continue outreach to under-represented students. 

The direct ice-to-ice synchronization of the WAIS Divide ice core with the Greenland Ice Core Chronology (GICC05) using cosmogenic 10Be is expected to reduce the uncertainty in the relative timing of more than 20 abrupt climate events in Greenland and Antarctica to a few decades. To achieve this goal the investigators will obtain a continuous high-resolution record of 10Be in the WAIS Divide core from 2850 to 3390 m depth, and compare the obtained 10Be record with existing 10Be records of the Greenland ice cores, including GISP2 and NGRIP. The scientists will separate 10Be from ~1000 ice samples of the WAIS Divide core and measure the 10Be concentration in each sample using accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS). Broader impacts of the 10Be measurements are that they will also provide information on the Laschamp event, a ~2000 year long period of low geomagnetic field strength around 41,000 years ago, and improve the calibration of the 14C dating method for organic samples older than 30,000 years. The broader impacts of the project include (1) the involvement and training of undergraduate students in ice core research and accelerator mass spectrometry measurements, (2) the incorporation of ice core and climate research into ongoing outreach programs at Purdue University and Berkeley SSL, (3) better understanding of abrupt climate changes in the past will improve our ability to predict future climate change, (4) evaluating the possible threat of a future geomagnetic excursion in the next few hundred years. This award does not require support in Antarctica.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we used a global signal of cosmic-ray produced 10Be in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet Divide core (WDC) to align the timescale of this core with other Antarctic and Greenland ice cores in order to constrain the relative timing of large climatic events in the Northern and Southern hemisphere. In a collaborative effort between the Space Science Lab at UC Berkeley and PRIME Lab at Purdue University, we performed 10Be measurements in more than 600 ice samples from 2850-3210 m depth in WDC. This depth interval corresponds to ages ranging from 31,000 to 48,000 yr before present (BP). The dataset includes ~300 samples from the Laschamp event, a period between 39,000-43,000 yr BP in which the Earth?s magnetic field was much weaker than today, an event that has been studied in other ice cores and can be used as an independent chronological marker that connects the timescales of these different ice cores. The 10Be measurements in WDC lead to several conclusions: (1) The 10Be concentrations in WDC samples older than 31,000 yr show almost no correlation with the oxygen isotope composition of the samples, indicating that the 10Be record of the WDC is mainly affected by variations in solar activity and magnetic field strength, which affect the atmospheric 10Be production on a global scale, rather than by changes in atmospheric mixing and/or snow accumulation rate, which affect the measured 10Be concentration in polar ice cores on a much smaller, localized scale. This implies that the 10Be record in WDC provides an excellent record for synchronizing the WD core with other Antarctic and Greenland ice cores. (2) To match the WDC 10Be data during the Laschamp event with other ice core 10Be records, we had to shift the WD2014 timescale at 41,000 yr BP by ~210 yr. This shift is within error consistent with the synchronization of Buizert et al. (Clim. Past 11, 153-173, 2015) who tied the methane record of WDC to the oxygen isotope records of Greenland ice cores and U,Th-dated Hulu Cave deposits. (3) The 10Be record in WDC between 31,000 and 39,000 yr BP shows at least one small enhancement (20-30% increase) that lasted ~2000 yr. This enhancement in 10Be appears to coincide with the Mono Lake geomagnetic excursion at 33-35 kyr BP, based on the GLOPIS-75 paleomagnetic record. The 10Be record in WDC thus confirms that the Mono Lake event represents a much less significant change in the geomagnetic field strength than the Laschamp event around 41,000 yr BP. (4) The 10Be record in WDC samples older than 45,000 yr BP shows significant variations that will help to further test and improve the calibration of the 14C dating method beyond 45,000 yr BP. The most recent calibration of the 14C/12C ratio (known as IntCal20) extends to 55,000 yr BP, but the 14C/12C ratios for samples older than 45,000 yr still have large uncertainties (of 3-20%), so further improvement is needed. 

In the future the continuous WDC 10Be record will provide an invaluable resource for understanding the chronology of global climate events, and the effects of variations in solar activity and geomagnetic field strength on atmospheric 10Be and 14C production.

The broader merits of the project included the training of several undergraduate students in ice core studies and the incorporation of methods and results of the WDC project in annual outreach activities at SSL.
